name: Under Argentina’s New President, Fuel Is Up 60%, and Diaper Prices Have Doubled.

children.name: Javier Milei warned that things would get worse before they got better
Now Argentines are living it
children.name_less: Argentines are experiencing a challenging situation.

children.name: Over the past two weeks, the owner of a hip wine bar in Buenos Aires saw the price of beef soar 73 percent, while the zucchini he puts in salads rose 140 percent
children.name_less: Food costs at a Buenos Aires wine bar have sharply increased, particularly beef and zucchini.

children.name: An Uber driver paid 60 percent more to fill her tank
children.name_less: Fuel costs for an Uber driver have significantly increased.

children.name: And a father said he spent twice as much on diapers for his toddler than he did last month
children.name_less: A father's spending on diapers doubled compared to the previous month.

children.name: In Argentina, a country synonymous with galloping inflation, people are used to paying more for just about everything
children.name_less: Inflation causes prices to consistently rise in Argentina.
Javier Milei cautioned about a potential worsening of the situation before improvement.

children.name: But under the country’s new president, life is quickly becoming even more painful
When Javier Milei was elected president on Nov. 19, the country was already suffering under the world’s third-highest rate of inflation, with prices up 160 percent from a year before
children.name_less: Javier Milei became president amid the country's severe inflation crisis, with prices having risen by 160 percent in a year.
Life is deteriorating under the new president.

children.name: But since Mr. Milei took office on Dec. 10 and quickly devalued the Argentine currency, prices have soared at such a dizzying pace that many in this South American country of 46 million are running new calculations on how their businesses or households can survive the far deeper economic crunch the country is already enduring
“Since Milei won, we’ve been worried all the time,” said Fernando González Galli, 36, a high school philosophy teacher in Buenos Aires
children.name_less: Milei's victory has caused constant worry for a Buenos Aires philosophy teacher.

children.name: Mr. Galli has been trying to cut back without making life worse for his two daughters, who are 6 years and 18 months old, including switching to a cheaper brand of diapers and racing to spend his Argentine pesos before their value disintegrates even further
children.name_less: Mr. Galli is economizing for his daughters' sake while coping with the rapid devaluation of Argentine pesos.

children.name: “As soon as I get my paycheck, I go buy everything I can,” he said
children.name_less: He spends his paycheck immediately on purchases.

children.name: Nahuel Carbajo, 37, an owner of Naranjo Bar, a trendy Buenos Aires wine bar, said that like most Argentines, he had become accustomed to regular price increases, but this past week went far beyond what even he was used to
children.name_less: Buenos Aires wine bar owner Nahuel Carbajo notes unprecedented price hikes beyond the usual increases Argentines are accustomed to.

children.name: Since Mr. Milei won, the price for the premium steak that Mr. Carbajo serves soared 73 percent, to 14,580 pesos, or roughly $18, per kilogram, about 2.2 pounds; a five-kilogram box of zucchini rose to 15,600 pesos from 6,500; and avocados cost 51 percent more than the beginning of this month
children.name_less: Mr. Milei's victory led to significant price increases for premium steak, zucchini, and avocados.

children.name: “There’s no way for salaries or people’s incomes to adapt at that speed,” Mr. Carbajo said
children.name_less: Salaries cannot adjust quickly to the change.

Mr. Milei's currency devaluation following his recent assumption of office has exacerbated the economic strain on Argentina, leading to rapidly increasing prices and concern for financial survival among its population.

children.name: Mr. Milei’s spokesman, Manuel Adorni, said accelerating inflation was the inevitable consequence of finally fixing Argentina’s distorted economy
“We’ve been left with a multitude of problems and unresolved issues that we have to start addressing,” he said
children.name_less: He highlighted the existence of numerous problems and issues that need attention.

children.name: “Inevitably, we will go through months of high inflation,” he added
children.name_less: High inflation is expected in the coming months.
Argentina's accelerating inflation is a result of economic adjustments, according to Mr. Milei's spokesman, Manuel Adorni.

children.name: Mr. Milei has warned Argentines that his plans to shrink the government and remake the economy will hurt at first
“I prefer to tell you the uncomfortable truth rather than a comfortable lie,” he said in his inaugural address, adding this past week that he wanted to end the country’s “model of decline”
children.name_less: He emphasized honesty over deceit and expressed a desire to halt the nation's decline in his inaugural speech.

children.name: Argentina’s economy has been mired in crisis for years, with chronic inflation, rising poverty and a currency that has plunged in value
children.name_less: Argentina is dealing with a long-term economic crisis characterized by high inflation, increasing poverty, and a depreciating currency.

children.name: The economic turmoil paved the way to the presidency for Mr. Milei, a political outsider who had spent years as an economist and television pundit railing against what he called corrupt politicians who destroyed the economy, often for personal gain
children.name_less: Mr. Milei, an economist and TV pundit critical of corrupt politicians, became president amidst economic turmoil.

children.name: During the campaign, he vowed to take a chain saw to public spending and regulations, even wielding an actual chain saw at rallies
children.name_less: He promised to significantly reduce public spending and regulations during his campaign.

children.name: After Mr. Milei’s victory, price increases began accelerating in expectation of his new policies
children.name_less: Mr. Milei's victory led to accelerated price increases due to anticipated policy changes.

children.name: The previous leftist government had used complicated currency controls, consumer subsidies and other measures to inflate the peso’s official value and keep several key prices artificially low, including for gas, transportation and electricity
children.name_less: The previous leftist government implemented complex controls and subsidies to artificially maintain low prices and overvalue the peso.

children.name: Mr. Milei vowed to undo all that, and he has wasted little time
children.name_less: Mr. Milei has quickly started reversing previous actions.

children.name: Two days after taking office, Mr. Milei began cutting government spending, including consumer subsidies
children.name_less: Mr. Milei started reducing government expenditure and consumer subsidies within two days of assuming office.

children.name: He also devalued the peso by 54 percent, putting the government’s exchange rate much closer to the market’s valuation
children.name_less: The government significantly devalued the peso to align with market valuation.

children.name: Economists said such measures were necessary to fix Argentina’s long-term financial problems
children.name_less: Economists recommend measures to resolve Argentina's persistent financial issues.
Mr. Milei cautions of initial pain from his economic and governmental reforms in Argentina.

children.name: But they also brought short-term pain in the form of even faster inflation
Some analysts questioned the lack of adequate safety nets for the poorest Argentines
children.name_less: Analysts express concerns over insufficient safety measures for Argentina's poorest citizens.

children.name: In November, prices rose 13 percent from October, according to government data
children.name_less: Prices increased by 13% in November compared to October.

children.name: Analysts predict prices will increase an additional 25 percent to 30 percent this month
children.name_less: Prices are expected to rise by 25-30% this month.

children.name: And from now until February, some economists are forecasting an 80 percent jump, according to Santiago Manoukian, the chief economist at Ecolatina, an economics consulting firm
children.name_less: Economists predict an 80% increase by February, says Santiago Manoukian of Ecolatina.

children.name: The forecasts are partly caused by soaring gas prices, which increased 60 percent from Dec. 7 to Dec. 13 and have a trickle-down effect on the economy
children.name_less: Gas price surge impacts economy.

children.name: The currency devaluation made imported products like coffee, electronic devices and gas immediately more expensive because they are priced in U.S. dollars
children.name_less: Currency devaluation led to higher prices for imports like coffee, electronics, and gas.

children.name: A monthly Netflix subscription in Argentina jumped 60 percent to 6,676 pesos, or $8.30, the day after the devaluation, for example
children.name_less: Netflix subscription in Argentina increased by 60 percent to 6,676 pesos following the devaluation.

children.name: It also prompted some domestic producers, including farmers and cattle ranchers, to increase prices to align them with their own rising costs
children.name_less: Domestic producers raised prices due to increasing costs.

children.name: With the chronic high inflation, labor unions often negotiate large raises to try to keep up, yet those wage increases are quickly eaten up by sharp price hikes
children.name_less: Labor unions negotiate large raises because of chronic high inflation, but rapid price increases diminish the value of these raises.

children.name: Informal workers, a list that includes nannies and street vendors, and who make up nearly half of the economy, also do not get such raises
children.name_less: Informal workers don't receive raises despite comprising almost half of the economy.
The actions led to increased inflation in the short term.

children.name: On Wednesday, Mr. Milei launched his next big steps to remake the government and economy with an emergency decree that significantly reduces the state’s role in the economy and eliminates a raft of regulations

The measure prohibits the state from regulating the rental real estate market and setting limits on fees that banks and health insurers can charge customers; changes labor laws to make it easier to fire workers while also placing limits on strikes; and turns state companies into corporations so they can be privatized
children.name_less: The law forbids state interference in rental market regulation, caps on financial and insurance fees, eases worker dismissal, restricts strikes, and facilitates state company privatization.

children.name: Many legal analysts immediately questioned the decree’s constitutionality, saying that Mr. Milei was trying to subvert Congress
children.name_less: Legal experts doubted the constitutionality of Mr. Milei's decree as an attempt to bypass Congress.

children.name: After the speech, people across Buenos Aires, like Jesusa Orfelia Peralta, 73, a retiree, took to the streets banging on pots to show their displeasure
children.name_less: Residents of Buenos Aires protested by banging on pots after a speech.

children.name: She worried that price increases would make proper health care too expensive for her and her husband
children.name_less: Health care costs concern woman for affordability.

children.name: Despite severe spinal problems, she said she did not hesitate to head out, using a walker, and vent her anger in public
children.name_less: Woman with spinal issues protests using walker.

children.name: she said
children.name_less: The sentence lacks content to summarize.
Mr. Milei issued an emergency decree on Wednesday to cut back government involvement in the economy and scrap numerous regulations.

children.name: Mr. Milei has sought to discourage protests by threatening to cancel welfare plans and fine anyone involved in demonstrations that block roads
Human rights groups have widely criticized such policies as restricting the right to protest peacefully
children.name_less: Policies limiting peaceful protest have been widely denounced by human rights groups.
Mr. Milei threatens to cancel welfare and fine protesters for road blockages.

children.name: For now, most Argentines are trying to figure out how to make ends meet in what often feels like both a complicated course in economics and a frenzied sprint to buy before prices rise again

“I always say that we are at university, and every day we sit for a difficult exam, every five minutes,” said Roberto Nicolás Ormeño, an owner of El Gauchito, a small empanada shop in downtown Buenos Aires
children.name_less: Roberto Nicolás Ormeño likens running his empanada shop in Buenos Aires to constantly facing a challenging university exam.

children.name: Mr. Ormeño said he had been scouring the market for his ingredients and changing suppliers almost every week, either because they increase prices too much or provide poorer quality products
children.name_less: Mr. Ormeño frequently switches suppliers due to price hikes or lower quality ingredients.

children.name: He is trying to avoid passing along too much of his price increases to customers, though he is unsure how long he can sustain that
children.name_less: He's trying to minimize raising prices for customers, but is uncertain about its sustainability.

children.name: “I see my frequent customers buying one dozen instead of two” dozen empanadas, he said
children.name_less: Customers are buying fewer empanadas than usual.

children.name: Marisol del Valle Cardozo, who has a 3-year-old daughter, has been cutting back in a bid to make ends meet, turning to cheaper brands and going out less
children.name_less: Marisol del Valle Cardozo is economizing by choosing less expensive brands and going out less to support her family.

children.name: “We don’t turn the air-conditioning on as much,” she said
children.name_less: She indicated they infrequently use air-conditioning.

children.name: “We decreased our plans on weekends from four times a month to just once”
children.name_less: Reduced weekend plans from weekly to monthly.

children.name: Ms. Cardozo, who works for a police department outside Buenos Aires, said that she got a raise this year, but that it is already not enough
children.name_less: Ms. Cardozo's recent raise is insufficient due to rising costs.

children.name: She also drives an Uber, but said that fare increases had not kept up with the soaring gas prices
children.name_less: Uber driver struggles with fare rates not matching rising gas prices.
Argentines are struggling to manage their finances amidst rapid inflation.

children.name: Despite the challenges, Ms. Cardozo said she remained a Milei supporter and was hoping his policies work
“We were living under a fantasy,” she said, referring to gas prices before the recent hike
children.name_less: Gas prices have recently increased, dispelling previous illusions of stable costs.

children.name: “If these adjustments are necessary to thrive in the end, they’re worth it”
children.name_less: Necessary adjustments are worthwhile for success.
Ms. Cardozo continues to support Milei and hopes his policies succeed.

name_less: Argentina faces significant inflation under the new president with a 60% rise in fuel costs and doubling diaper prices.
